OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_DEFAULT_ROLE's "member" just default value, but it can be re-defined to any value in any case.

openstack_dashboard/test/unit/api/test_k.message:
I think it is better to mock api.keystone.DEFAULT_ROLE inside a test rather than resetting it in tearDown. We cleaned up most usage of tearDown (while some still exist for corner cases).

mock.patch.object() should work according to my small test.

 >>> from unittest import mock
 >>> from openstack_dashboard import api
 >>> api.keystone.DEFAULT_ROLE
 >>> api.keystone.DEFAULT_ROLE = 1
 >>> api.keystone.DEFAULT_ROLE
 1
 >>> m = mock.patch.object(api.keystone, 'DEFAULT_ROLE', new=None)
 >>> m.start()
 >>> api.keystone.DEFAULT_ROLE
 >>> api.keystone.DEFAULT_ROLE = 10
 >>> api.keystone.DEFAULT_ROLE
 10
 >>> m.stop()
 >>> api.keystone.DEFAULT_ROLE
 1
 >>>

deployment/cephadm/ceph-client.yaml.message:
This part will be executed only when we have no mons ( == 0) and the ceph_nfs group contains at least a node. 
In this case we need to load the variables generated at step1 (they're not set as facts as per tripleo best practices) and we load them here to make them available to the nfs set of tasks.

The reason I moved this part here, instead of executing it via the cephadm.yaml playbook, is that we need the client role being executed before any ceph bit, and including it in the cephadm playbook resulted in a multiple execution of the same role which causes a big waste of time for large clusters.

doc/source/admin/external-authentication.message: Is there another safer example we could use, like kerberos? We're still allowing external auth so it would still be best to document it as long as we're also including a disclaimer.
let me setup kerberos on my dev environment to get an accurate example

The `CAUTION` is good.
+1 for Colllen, this example part can be kept.
Do we want to recommend that x509 "only" be used with federation?

Yes. X.509 should be for federation only. External auth is only useful in a situation where the all the identities are managed by a single IDP and in a single monolithic domain. And it cannot be used in conjunction with federation either. X.509, on the other hand, have a lot more attributes then just the username mapping and it shouldn't be limited by external auth.

This is the main issue, right? Any external auth can't be used with more than a single domain and that domain is hardcoded with SetEnv? If so, kerberos isn't really a better example than X.509, and we might as well keep the old example but deprecate external auth altogether.

Right, there are a number of issues with Kerberos.

1. Single domain
2. Require separate auth URL (i.e. /krb/identity/v3/auth/tokens)
3. Limited number of attributes about the identity, just name and domain.
4. It's not compatible with other external auth mechanisms. i.e. can't enable them at the same time.

Given that external auth only conveying a single attribute (REMOTE_USER), I am not not sure how useful it is in a large scale production environment. I am fine with deprecating it.

doc/source/devref/functional_testing.rst.message: This could go into even greater detail about what keystone thinks functional testing is. For example, how does this differ from the functional-like tests we have in the keystone/tests/unit/test_v3_*.py modules. That might be a great way to set the stage for the rest of the document.

For the sake of readability, the two items in this list could be consolidated in to the above paragraph.

  ... available under `keystone_tempest_plugin`. The first is a voting
  job that exposes both the v2 and v3 endpoint (more details can be
  elaborated on here). The second is a non-voting job that exposes only
  the v3 endpoint, but takes additional steps to setup things required for
  federated workflows in order to run federated test cases (more details
  can be elaborated on here).

This is a great place to explain the role of the devstack plugin. For example, it could say that the whole purpose of the devstack plugin is to give the maintainers of the project the flexibility to setup keystone in specific ways before testing (using hooks from devstack, etc..).

As a developer reading the document, it gives me an idea of why this devstack thing exists within keystone, why I should use it, and when its usage is appropriate.

It could also describe when in the functional testing process I need to contribute to the devstack plugin. For example, if I want to develop some new tests for a new thing, my first step might be to contribute to the devstack plugin that adds functionality for the new thing. Then my next step would be writing tests, but those live somewhere else, etc..

> In general, applications should try to trap their own, internal errors, and display a helpful message in the browser.

If someone has a need for name-based virtualhosts, they are free to configure it that way, but the instructions as written are also correct for simple deployments and do not need to be changed.

keystone/token/providers/common.py.message:
style remark: if you're leaving a comment with your name, make it of the form:

  NOTE(edmondsw): Also set ...
Just make it true for all roles, and the fix is backwards compatible.  There is nothing special about admin.  If the conf values are set and they don't match, explicitly set is_admin_project = False.

that rewriting of policy files is exactly what is going to start happening, though, making all roles global-capable. That is only safe, for the reasons I described above, if we check for the admin role here.

All roles aren't magically going to become global - that would require rewriting the policy files. admin is by convention the only role that is used across projects but all roles work the same way here. 

keystoneauth is required to expose the flag via auth_token middleware. auth_token middleware and oslo.context are what is required to do enforcement properly.

Right - ayoung and i had a debate over this as to whether it was necessary to put true - because True is the default, it's False we're really interested in here.

What i most dislike is you are looking for the admin role rather than just saying everything is in the admin project. I don't want to make the string 'admin' any more special than it already is.

But yea - if nothing is in the token then we assume True. Adding True here doesn't buy us anything.

checking for the admin role is essential. Otherwise as soon as the code and policy files for nova, etc. are updated to check for is_admin_project=True and consider that global, ALL role assignments will be global for environments that don't have the admin project specified in keystone's conf. Doing that for admin is backward compatible because that's the current behavior for admin roles... but doing that for anything else is most definitely NOT backward compatible.

And the fact that keystoneauth will assume True if is_admin_project isn't in the token only helps those that use keystoneauth... which is not everyone. So doing this here rather than just in keystoneauth means it works for everyone, not just users of keystoneauth.

Why? from a client side we default to is_admin_project True if nothing is set so this is exactly the same. 

also just 'admin' in token_data['roles']
we could add a comment here saying that this *has* to be after we populate the roles, because in order to set the admin project we need to know the roles a user has.

I don't see how this is different. When no value is set in the token then auth_token middleware will default the value to True. 

The only value that actually matters here is is_admin_project=False.

https://github.com/openstack/keystonemiddleware/blob/dfd53e55512cba6a8b7e69ac5bf7bea172dfe6b1/keystonemiddleware/auth_token/_request.py#L63

keystone/common/fernet_key_store/backend.message: Add a parameter to these to indicate which repository it is.  Create an enumerated value that, at a minimum has `token` and `credential` as its type.

I'm not sure I agree with this part. A fernet repository is just a set of keys somewhere, and currently that somewhere is on disk. We don't expect the keys to know what they are suppose to be used for. Instead we leave it to whatever needs the encrypting done. If something needs to have a value encrypted or decrypted, it needs to specifically say which repository it needs to interact with [0] [1]. This makes the fernet token provider responsible for interacting with the repository dedicated to token encryption. The same applies with the fernet credentials provider. The only relationship the current key repository directories have with the system that uses them is the default naming convention (`/etc/keystone/fernet-keys/`, `/etc/keystone/credential-keys/`). But there is nothing stopping someone from swapping those values through config to be something more obscure.

I think having the drivers and keys keep track of what they are encrypting is unnecessary coupling if we already expect manager to interact with the proper key repository.


[0] https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/686f9d583eaa5f015d6b8b995c2f4243392ffbce/keystone/credential/providers/fernet/core.py#L45-L46

[1] https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/686f9d583eaa5f015d6b8b995c2f4243392ffbce/keystone/token/providers/fernet/token_formatters.py#L59-L62
merge this with the create_directory function above.

If you are going to include this, then also have an "inject key" and "extract key" function.  To start, they can be unimplemented in the default impl, but really this is workflow separate from accessing keys.  Most real deployments can't do this on the Keystone server, but rather do it as part of config management.

keystone/common/fernet_key_store/core.py.message: if it only bypasses all the calls and params, it doesn't need to implement them. see https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/83e3c00/keystone/common/manager.py#L185

What is going to use this api, other managers? The `keystone-manage` CLI? I can see a use case for other managers to be able to pass something to a separate API to encrypt or decrypt it [0], but I'm not sure if exposing key rotation and repository management in an API is the right approach. I could be missing a use case though. The current approach to our file-based repository management is to call utility functions from `keystone-manage` to make new keys, rename them in rotations, and remove them when necessary. I think allowing other storage mechanisms for fernet keys would consist of making the existing utility methods pluggable through config without exposing their management functions through a manager class, but through `keystone-manage`.

That way, regardless of the fernet key store backend you have defined in your configuration, you should be able to do `keystone-manage fernet_setup` and get a set of file-based keys (like you do today), or a repository of fernet keys somewhere else.


[0] https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/686f9d583eaa5f015d6b8b995c2f4243392ffbce/keystone/credential/core.py#L68-L70

indeed the ideal solution to race conditions that would allow for migrations to succeed without violating the policy, is through the complete redesign of the (anti-)affinity feature on placement. We discussed this a meeting and I signed up for the redesigned work. Unfortunately, things turned out to be much more complex than I anticipated.

I was almost finished with the redesigned and PoC implementation using aggregates, but the fact that there are customizable rules "max_server_per_host" per individual group makes it much more complex. I wouldn't propose a redesign with the loss of that functionality (even if it is not widely used).

The redesign I came up with consisted of using the aggregate UUID as the group UUID, as the instances and resource providers need a resource in common to check against and the generation ID from the resource providers ensured no 2 requests would perform the same action in parallel in different resource providers, while having the aggregate in common (I added a new placement API to create/update the aggregate based on aggregate UUID instead of resource provider UUID). Traits also would require new placement API to interact on them instead of on resource providers, so they are almost equivalent but the semantics using traits look too "hacky" while using aggregates it makes much more logical sense. A lot of stitching was required to prevent the requests themselves from being racy because it all relied on a cascade of successes:
1) it would need to set the aggregate first (a parallel request would fail and then re-evaluate the candidates)
2) it would then need to claim the allocations, which could then fail if the host didn't have enough resources during claim (they could have been claimed in parallel), and then the aggregate update needs to be reverted
3) finally the instance would need to build successfully on the compute, otherwise the claim needs to be reverted, and then aggregate also reverted.

Steps #2 and #3 can lead to exponencial cascading failures, where the parallel request that previously failed step #1 would then re-evaluate and agree to land on the same resource provider (if policy=affinity) as picked by the first request that created the aggregate (however, that had not yet successfully built the instance). Then, if the first request failed step #2 and #3, not only would need to revert that, but the parallel requests would also need to fail and be reverted. Affinity ended up being much harder than anti-affinity.

Finally, introducing the max_server_per_host to the mix. The closest semantic was a resource semantic, like MEMORY_MB, VCPU, etc that gets subtracted. So, this is a variable that could be changed on the fly by the operator, and then needs to be updated on placement on all the affected resource providers. While you add it to the mix, you have a 4th item in the cascade above that needs to succeed. While also having extra requests for adding the resource to the resource_provider when it makes sense and subsequently updating it. The more requests, the racier. I could solve part of those issues with some extra APIs to bundle some requests together. However, the final nail in the complexity coffin was that there was no generation_ID to prevent the max_server_per_host from being racy. Therefore the placement semantics would need to be updated to address that.

Anyway, it turned out to be a tremendous amount of work, so I decided to try something simpler (this patch). For my customer's use case (which is only for anti-affinity), this patch solves the race condition problem.

specs/xena/qos-minimum-guaranteed-packet.message:
Is egress/ingress meant from the perspective of instance port, softswitch or compute host?

Please note the possible combinations too, like traffic that flows from one vm to another vm on the same host: that is ingress and egress at the same time for the softswitch, but neither ingress nor egress for the compute.

Also I'm wondering how we want to address packet processing capacity consumed by incoming traffic? In a fully cooperative environment I guess the admin could come up with an educated guess of outgoing/incoming packet ratio and reserve packet processing capacity based on that. It seems to me we cannot make guarantees if the environment is not fully cooperative. Or can we?

> Is egress/ingress meant from the perspective of instance port, softswitch or compute host?

> For QoS I would keep that direction is from the instance's perspective:
> https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-qos.html#supported-qos-rule-types

instance's port perspective as in case of min bw. I've added some explanation under this codeblock.

> Please note the possible combinations too, like traffic that flows from one vm to another 
> vm on the same host: that is ingress and egress at the same time for the softswitch, but 
> neither ingress nor egress for the compute.

If there are two VMs A and B on the same host. Both A and B has both ingress and egress packet rate guarantees. Then when A sends a packet to B that packet is counted against the egress guarantee of A and the ingress guarantee of B. But both resource usages are counted against the same OVS resource inventory. So in case of same host traffic we allocate more resource in placement that actually used by the OVS to move the packet. This does not break the guarantee but it results in sub optimal workload placement if the majority of the traffic is between VMs on the same host. Honestly I don't see how can we optimize this during schedule time.

> Also I'm wondering how we want to address packet processing capacity consumed by incoming traffic? 
> In a fully cooperative environment I guess the admin could come up with an educated guess of 
> outgoing/incoming packet ratio and reserve packet processing capacity based on that. It seems to 
> me we cannot make guarantees if the environment is not fully cooperative. Or can we?

I'm not an expert here. I assume that if OVS can drop the incoming packet cheaply at the point when it arrives then we can provide guarantees. If dropping incoming traffic is as expensive as forwarding them, then I agree that we cannot handle excessive ingress traffic.

For QoS I would keep that direction is from the instance's perspective:
https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-qos.html#supported-qos-rule-types
Does this new rule type apply to ports not belonging to instances?

It definitely only apply to bound ports. If the port is not bound by Nova (I don't know who else bounds ports in Neutron) then Nova cannot guarantee that the resource allocation is created in placement. In theory service bounding ports in Neutron can look at the resource_request of the port and make the necessary resource allocation in placement to keep the consistency. However enforcing this is not in scope either of the Nova or the Neutron spec.

I've added a sentence here to clarify this.

I assume we only have a relatively static packet processing capability when we use DPDK based OVS and a set number of CPU cores are exclusively assigned to packet processing. Is this correct?

If it is, this also may be worth mentioning here and adding to the docs in the implementation.

> I assume we only have a relatively static packet processing capability when we use DPDK based OVS and a set number of CPU cores are exclusively assigned to packet processing. Is this correct?
> 
> If it is, this also may be worth mentioning here and adding to the docs in the implementation.

the packet processing capacity of an OVS instance depends on may factors. Number of CPU cores, the exclusive usage of such cores, NUMA location of the OVS cpu core compared to the location of the cpu core of the VM (cross NUMA talk is more expansive then same NUMA). So to be able to define the packet processing capacity of a specific deployment, the admin needs to do measurement in that setup with a relativistic traffic mix. Fortunately the admin can start with a pretty conservative estimate, do the configuration based on that, monitor the load, and increase the capacity if the monitoring proves that plenty of capacity is still available.

This will be documented in the new admin guide for this feature.

Feedback from the PTG: Please investigate what would it mean if we report the packet processing capacity per OVS bridge as an alternative.

The big advantage of having the pps resource represented on the OVS bridge, on the same place as the bandwidth resource, is that it would simplify the overall design. It means that we could still keep the assumption that the resource request of the port is always fulfilled from a single resource provider. Therefore the format of the port.resource_request  and the port.bindig:profile.allocation does not need to change. 

One drawback is that if we define packet processing capacity on the bridges then if there are multiple bridges then the overall packet processing capacity of the whole OVS would need to be statically split between the bridges. And multiple bridges are possible, even in the simple case of having one phynet bridge for vlan traffic and one tunneling bridge for vxlan traffic. 

Also in case of bandwidth the actual resource is behind the physnet bridge, the physical interface the bridge is connected to so the resource is dedicated to the bridge. But in case of packet processing the actual resource is not at all dedicated to the given bridge. So while we can assign a portion of the overall resource to the bridge this assignment would never represent the reality well.

Also if we keep the resource globally on OVS then the host only traffic can be better accounted for as it does go through the OVS but it does not go through physnet or tunneling bridges.

Also while the currently proposed design change is significant it makes the solution more future proof. E.g. for the case when the IP pool resource handling will be refactored to use the port's resource_request then we anyhow need to be able to handle another resource provider that will not be the same as any of the existing ones as the IP addresses are shared resource between multiple host. 


[1] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-qos-min-bw.html#limitations
Done, described in the Nova spec and referred it from this spec

Feedback from the PTG: In case of OVS with vnic_type=normal it is OK to have a directionless resource as OVS in this case is CPU limited and that CPU is shared between directions. However in case of VOS with vnic_type=direct (e.g. when OVS is hardware offloaded) the different directions are handled by different hardware queues and therefore they have independent packet processing capacity. Therefore an OVS with offload should report a direction aware resource while the normal OVS should report a directionless resource. 

This also means that when the port has vnic_type=normal then the neutron should put the sum of the requested pps from the QoS rules to the resource_request as a directionless request. But when the vnic_type is direct then neutron should but the two QoS rules as two independent request towards the direction aware resource.

1) a single neutron network has two physnet segment. In this case the routed net feature already needs to make sure that the proper compute is selected. 
2) two neutron network has different physnets configured and two computes has different OVS configuration so that one compute has access to one of the physnet while the other compute has access to the other physnet. Today nova scheduling does not consider physnet availability in this case. Nova can select the wrong compute and the the port binding will fail.

I think the physnet trait originally came into the picture to handle the following situation. We have 2 device connected to two different physnets handled by the same agent. Both device providing bandwidth inventory. Then a VM boot with a port with bandwidth request would mean nova + placement decides which device is selected for the port. If this decision does not consider the physnet then if the port's network connected to a different physnet that the device the bandwidth is allocated from then the port bindig would fail. To avoid such failure we introduced the physnet trait so that the scheduling selects the proper device.

So in case of pps there is a bit different scenario as we have only one OVS agent per host so we have a less ambiguous situation. But simply selecting the OVS on a compute host based on the vnic type and the available bandwidth or pps inventory does not mean that this OVS has connectivity towards the physnet the port's network represents. I think this could result in the same binding failure as above if some of the computes has access to one physnet while the other computes has access only to a different physnet.

Yep, my main point wanted to be that scheduling based on the availability of physnet(s) is a valid use case. But - in contrast to the minimum bw support, where the physical bw resource (ie. the NIC enslaved to a physical bridge) is naturally part of a physnet - the min pps has no (one-to-one) logical connection to a physnet. So if we want to support the physnet based scheduling it may be better to do that purposefully in its own spec instead of doing it as a limited side effect of the min pps feature.

What format will be accepted by nova? Nova and Placement does not interpret this in any way, right? In what scope does this have to be unique?

Good question.

Nova might need to correlate this in case of a direct port, where the nova PCI claim needs to be driven by the placement decision. I.e. a  direct port requested bandwidth, so nova allocated bandwidth in placement from a PF. Then nova has to make sure that PCI claim process selects VF from the same PF. Today it is done by iterating the PCI requests of the instance and checking if there is a corresponding request group in the placement allocation. This only works today as the request group requester_id is the port_id and also the requester_id of the PCI request is the port_id. This needs to be changed in nova. Probably we still need to store the port_id as the requester_id and also store the group_id in the RequestGroup in a new field. 

Anyhow from nova perspective the group id in the resource_request needs to be a string. Nova does not store it in the db. The placement API has a length limit of 64 for the group id. I.e.: r'[a-zA-Z0-9_-]{1,64}'

Placement requires that the group id is unique in a given allocation_candidate request. This means that each VM lifecycle operation (that results in scheduling) needs to have unique group ids. E.g. if there are multiple ports in a VM boot request then each group in each port needs to have a unique id. Also because ports can be added to a running VM then later a VM can be moved, the newly added port needs to have unique group ids in the scope of each port of the VM. So the best would be if Neutron could generate a uuid for each group. However if this is not feasible then a unique group id per port is the strict minimum we need. Then nova needs to combine the port_id and the group id to get a fully unique id for the lifecycle operation.

Bottom line, I propose to have a unique id (UUID) per deployment.
Done

After talking with Bence we figured that the best thing to do is to deterministically generate a new unique UUID from the combination of the existing UUIDs (port_id, and the ids of the rules in the QoS policy). Regarding the second option. We have the port_id that is unique in the scope of the deployment, and we have the QoS rule_id that is unique at least within a given QoS policy (I assume that a give policy cannot have two rules with the same rule_id). As the port has a single QoS policy therefore the QoS rule_id also unique within the scope of a port. So one way to deterministically generate a new unique id is to use the existing UUIDs and combine them. The 64 length limit does not allow a textual combination of the port_id and the QoS rule_id. Also we can have more than one rule_id per group as different traffic directions need different rules. So we might need to combine more than two UUIDs. I'm wondering if using binary XOR on UUIDs are good enough to generate a combined but unique UUID.

Let me know what you think.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/ta.message: so in the extrnal_cluster case we're passing -n client.{{ user }}

This command is still incomplete since we need to pass:

--config /etc/ceph/ceph.conf
--keyring /etc/ceph/client.manila.keyring


and we need to make sure they're present on all the controller nodes before
this playbook is executed.

As per conversation w/ the Ceph team, the systemd units in both TripleO deployed and external Ceph cluster are not controlled by cephadm, but pacemaker is the component designed to manage the lifecycle of ganesha.
This means we need to avoid starting the systemd units, and we can just render the related templates.

/me is going to rework this part and fill the gap

we're giving here to the ceph cli the ability to select a specific keyring when the 'admin' one is not available: in this context, we're rendering the ceph.client.manila.keyring, and we want to use that keyring against the external ceph cluster.

Perhaps add a comment like the following to capture this idea in the code and not just the review?

# have ceph cli use manila cephx keyring if admin is not available
if true, the option -n client.{{ user }} will be added to the cli
Thanks for explaining that. Do you want to add that as a code comment so people know why that option was used here?

manifests/phases/executors.yaml.message:
Hi Kostyantyn. Could you please explain the purpose of this change? 

> We need this to make sure that airship container type is properly tested and we know that its working.

That seems to me a weird reason. First of all, when we implemented an Airship type of GenericContainer, before merging it we had to be sure that it's properly tested and working. So, turns out we knew that we proposed potentially raw solution which may not work as expected, am I correct? If so, then testing container functionality in this way does not seem right approach to me.
Secondly, Airship type of generic container used by iso-build-image executor, so we already have an example. Why we need to touch another executor then?
And the last one, the toolbox image, which is used here, is a KRM based image and contains krm function inside. Do you see a contradiction in the fact that KRM based image used in regular container?

As I understand, the executor you touched was working properly, you just wanted to test it within Airship type instead of KRM. If so, it should be done on a lab and shouldn't come to master branch, IMO. What benefits will bring us switching container type in master?

> hat seems to me a weird reason. First of all, when we implemented an Airship type of GenericContainer, before merging it we had to be sure that it's properly tested and working. So, turns out we knew that we proposed potentially raw solution which may not work as expected, am I correct?

You are not correct. Any solution is raw until tested in production. I don't get your implications Ruslan, sorry, we have unit tests, we have container running it tests. The more anything is used, the more bugs will be uncovered and fixed. That is how software development process works.

> Secondly, Airship type of generic container used by iso-build-image executor, so we already have an example. Why we need to touch another executor then?
To increase usage of the container, and to uncover potential problems.

> And the last one, the toolbox image, which is used here, is a KRM based image and contains krm function inside. Do you see a contradiction in the fact that KRM based image used in regular container?
I don't see any contradiction, I see that it was a temporary solution with the flaws that you point out (Container should we unaware of what created it, KRM, Airship, Kubernetes or manual startup)

> As I understand, the executor you touched was working properly, you just wanted to test it within Airship type instead of KRM
Yes, you are right

> If so, it should be done on a lab and shouldn't come to master branch, IMO.
You are not correct, master branch is exactly for changes like these, that is how release management works. You push to master, you make release candidate, you release it. And that is where we are going. 

> What benefits will bring us switching container type in master?
Switching container types in master? sorry i don't understand what you mean.

Python 2.7.10 (default, Sep  8 2015, 17:20:17)

I prefer to use python built in functions instead of duplicating code.

I agree with you partially.i looked into what exactly platform.py is doing to figure out the distro. It tries to read "/etc/lsb-release". There are different files in /etc which we can read to find the distro. Any of lsb-release, os-release, redhat-release will be fine IMO. I am just using one of them.
Also by calling platform.linux_distribution(), we are introducing one more function call in the flow, and some exception handling code following it. Where as currently i am just opening a file to read the contents which is an efficient way compared to former. May be our concern here is,which file to rely on among the three that i have mentioned?
What do you plan to catch here? I don't think we need except clauses "just in case"

I agree. But isn't it fail safe?May be error while parsing the content, or permission issues( though we run as root in case initrd changes induce file permission issues). I am ok to remove if you think it's really not needed:)
Will it be ok to remove this case?

According to https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/GRUB_2?rd=Grub2 grub-install shouldn't be called on fedora with EFI. Why not just do grub-install only if system is not Fedora? In this case L115-125 and L147-159 are not needed.

I am not sure if i get your points clearly. But i'l try to answer them. There are two options to address this issue.

Option 1: Take the back up and restore it once the EFI partition is mounted. We do not need to call grub-install.

Option 2: Take the back up of EFI. Call grub-install let it install what ever is needed(just like in any other case). Replace EFI related stuff as grub-install will only break for EFI.

In either way, L115-125 is needed to backup the existing contents before mounting efi partition and L147-159 to restore. The reason being, once we mount the /boot/EFI on efi partition the contents are lost, then how does it get the boot loader? 

I prefer option 2 over 1, since grub-install only breaks for EFI and i'd prefer to run it and take care of only EFI related parts leaving the rest of the system intact.
grub_cfg may be set to '/boot/efi/EFI/fedora/grub.cfg' for Fedora. In this case L169-174 are not needed.
For the same reason as i explained, i want to retain the original one as is which is where it looks in non efi systems.
Looks like this is only used in is_fedora_distro methd. Thus the variable scope should be contained in the method.
As per the review comments i received for previous submissions i have made this choice.I'd like to watch for more comments on this before changing it.
I personally prefer something like if 'fedora' in f.readline().

+1. 
I am going to make changes accordingly.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/ta.message:
I think this can be reworked w/o having a bash script that should be generated, copied and executed.
We already have the dictionary providing the input here (that can be passed via tripleo_run_cephadm as an ansible var) and it's something like:

```
tripleo_cephadm_config_map: {"mgr": {"mgr/cephadm/autotune_memory_target_ratio": 0.5}, "osd": {"osd_memory_target_autotune": true, "osd_numa_node": 0}}
```

Now, if you just add a new ceph-ansible module that uses the same functions that are already implemented and used by the other components (rgw, mds, monitoring stack, ceph_fs, keys), you can just add it here the following task:

- name: Config map
  ceph_config:
    cluster: "ceph"
    data: "{{ tripleo_cephadm_config_map | to_json }}"
  environment:
    CEPH_CONTAINER_IMAGE: "{{ tripleo_cephadm_container_ns + '/' + tripleo_cephadm_container_image + ':' + tripleo_cephadm_container_tag }}"
    CEPH_CONTAINER_BINARY: "{{ tripleo_cephadm_container_cli }}"

 
which is able to apply the settings against the ceph cluster.
I created a quick module [1] that can be used for this purpose.

The advantage of using an ansible module instead of rendering a bash script here is minimize the extra logic (just 1 ansible task "to rule them all"), you can easily extend it in the future providing more parameters (e.g. you need additional config options) and you can improve the module relying on the data structure passed as an input instead of working with multiple parts.
In addition, this maintain consistency on the approach used for the other components, other than the style adopted in the playbook.
Let's talk more about it, but I basically tested this way and work pretty well. 

[1] https://github.com/fmount/tripleo-xena/blob/master/scripts/ceph_config_module.py

The one case that won't catch is if the VIM strategy was in the "ready-to-apply" state and the dcmanager was restarted (which will eventually cause it to re-execute this state). But... in that case, we don't know whether the strategy was created by this orchestration run or was created at some point in the past, so deleting/recreating it is probably the right thing to do.

and then return.

We are using the same logic as kube/firmware and upgrade

So the latest changeset now behaves the same as them

Good point - so that would apply (I think) in the case where we were building a VIM strategy in a subcloud and then the dcmanager was restarted and came back up (and re-entered this state) before the build was completed. We would now fail this step instead of waiting for the strategy build to complete?

However, in the other types of orchestration (firmware, upgrades, k8s), it looks to me like it would do the same thing - fail the strategy step if the dcmanager restarted while the VIM strategy was building. Can you confirm?

If the above is correct, I would prefer that we make the patch orchestration behave the same way as the other types of orchestration. Long term, we should be restructuring the patch orch to use the same state infrastructure as the other types of orchestration.

This makes sense that it doesn't exist on the AIO-DX since the Mon/OSDs in this case are managed by SM as opposed to pmon. But if controller-1 is unlocked, then I think you will need to perform an 'sm-unmanage service ceph-mon' in this scenario to ensure that the after the '/etc/init.d/ceph stop mon' is executed below SM doesn't come along and restart it.

Actually, now that I think about it some more. controller-0 will not have a monitor running in this rollback scenario since after rollback it will be the standby controller. I don't think we need to do anything in this case and actually don't need to call this function at all if it's an AIO (SX or DX)

Based on the comments we're disabling the storage monitor on controller-1 so that when controller-0 comes up we aren't sending stale ceph data. If there's only one monitor active at a time in AIO-DX deployments, we should be good with the latest revision.
I moved the logic check up into the one place that was setting the flag to call this method

Looks like this code was put in place when the only supported Ceph configuration was a 2+M+N system. In that scenario, we have a 3 monitor quorum active. Basically this code is not written from the perspective of a AIO-SX (using 1 monitor managed by pmon) an AIO-DX (using one monitor managed by SM). Basically it should   still handle 2+N/2+M+N configs with 3 monitor quorums.

swift/container/backend.py.message:
OK so this change simplifys this code.. and maybe not for the better. But if we're going to be tracking progress in the CleaveContext then if we get to a place where we're at the "end" earlier or beyond the end, then marking at zero I think makes sense. The shardrange will be FOUND and then CLEAVED which by that stage it'll have it's true object_count.. if it happens to be huge once it becomes ACTIVE it'll shard again (which I think is the correct action).

It may come back small and I guess we just have ourselves a small tail.

We could just push forward and search try and get the next upper and continue, that's the other option.. but if we fall back to that, then we're back and small tails. And the whole point is to track this containers progress.

Real question then becomes. What happens if there is a rebalance.. I guess the new scanner looses it's progress.. so maybe we need to fall back to an imperfect, calculate progress from already found shards... if they are alittle out of whack, then worst case my first paragraph of this comment comes back into play. And of course, that only effects auto-sharding not s-m-s-r which will scan in batches but on the same replica until it's done.

we use this to get the last_upper and possibly to get the progress if not given...could we change the signature to just pass in last_upper and progress? in fact, could we just pass in a context and have this method mutate ctx.progress and ctx.scan_cursor??? 

IDK which interface I prefer, so will mull on it for a while. But something about falling back to existing_ranges if progress is not given seems more complicated than necessary.

here we're still using the potentially unreliable progress based on existing ranges, but without the check on states

ShardRangeList provides an object count summation, wonder if we could use that?

I wonder if we should do something like: http://paste.openstack.org/show/806300/

So it'll hit the DB to get a reliable progress, but this should only happen rarely if ever, but would mean we don't have cater to the non-reiable method.

ok, this works and is simple

Tracking progress independently of existing range object counts is an improvement.

However, this is still a 'look ahead and squash in next tiny range' approach. It is based on a potentially inaccurate estimate of the shard size because it is based on comparing object_count to progress. IF we decide to make the estimate more accurate we'd need to make a look ahead db query here (which gets back to the 'wasted db query' issue discussed on other patches).

If we do the minimum size check and squash in the caller, rather than here, then IF we decide to improve the accuracy of the final shard size using a db query then I suspect it will be much less disruptive. i.e. this method always returns the shard range it finds, with an estimate or accurate shard size, then caller decides whether to squash the final shard into the penultimate.

But, maybe we won't ever make it more accurate :/
